conclusion: The light source is initially positioned above the objects, casting shadows A, B, C, and D on the ground.
The shadows are formed due to the obstruction of light by the objects.
The light source moves forward, closer to the objects.
As the light source moves forward, the angle of incidence of the light rays changes.
The shadows will shift towards the direction opposite to the movement of the light source.
Shadows A, B, C, and D will move backward relative to their current positions.
When the light source moves closer to the objects, the angle of the light rays becomes more acute.
This results in the shadows becoming larger because the light rays are spread out more over the ground.
The size of the shadows will increase as the light source moves forward.
Shadows A, B, C, and D will move backward and increase in size if the light source moves forward above the objects.
